newsitem.title: INDIA: India PM sees no threat to ruling coalition.
newsitem.headline: India PM sees no threat to ruling coalition.

text.p: Indian Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said on Tuesday he was sure of a solution to the crisis in his ruling United Front coalition, stemming from the planned withdrawal of a regional party.

"I am sure we would be able to sort it out in the next meeting of the steering committee (of the United Front)," Gujral told Asian News International in a videotaped interview. "I am absolutely certain we will be able to bridge the difficulties."

He said he had already spoken to two leaders of the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK) after the southern-based party issued a statement on Monday saying it planned to withdraw its four ministers from the government, but that it would continue to support the coalition.

"I do not see any possibility or any probability or any chance of a strain on the government," he said. "...I am sure that wisdom has prevailed already that we must accommodate each others' point of view."
The DMK had said on Monday that the coalition had compromised on its dignity by allowing some of its partners to force their own agenda in the coalition.

It did not explain the differences, which party leaders said were targeted at the Communist Party of India-Marxist (CPI-M), which had insisted on the removal from the coalition of a breakaway group of Gujral's Janata Dal party.

The DMK accounts for less than 20 of the United Front's 178 lawmakers in India's 545-seat lower house of federal parliament. The coalition's survival depends on vital support from the Congress party's 140 members.

The DMK's salvo was the latest in a chain reaction stemming from a split on July 5 in Gujral's Janata Dal party, whose then leader Laloo Prasad Yadav formed a breakaway Rashtriya Janata Dal but stayed on in the 15-party alliance.
